She has been operating her business for the past 10 years and is confident that an investment will be a productive one for her. 
 
Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Perveen.

loans.use: To buy embroidery material

loans.name: Raquelin

texts.en:
This is Raquelin.  She is 45 years old and is a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Rolando, a factory worker. She has three children, the youngest is still in high school and the two eldest are now working.  Raquelin, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating their business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.   

Raquelin owns a variety store. She buys groceries like canned goods, condiments, milk, sugar, and commodities that are needed in every household. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and people from the local community.  She earns a minimum of 600 PHP in sales every day.  Aside from this, Raquelin also sews rugs that she sells to stall owners in the market.  

Raquelin is requesting a loan amounting to 8,000 PHP to help her buy more grocery items to sell and more materials for her rug making business.  With the help of God, she strongly believes that her business will be more prosperous.

Raquelin hopes that her business will continue to prosper and she also wishes that her family will always have good health. She never fails to attend to the fellowship* every week, as it inspires her to grow more spiritually and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy grocery items and rug-making materials

loans.name: Badarch

texts.en: Badarch is 60 years old and lives with his wife in a ger -- a Mongolian yurt,  in the Tosontsengel province of Mongolia. He started his business 11 years ago by planting vegetables and selling them. He runs this business operation in his hometown. In the future, he plans to expand his business. His wife helps him manage the family business. Badarch is a hard-working and diligent man who says "With this bank loan, I want to expand my business. In the future, I plan to open a grocery shop."  He is requesting a loan for 1,000,000 MNT to buy a tractor for his business.

loans.use: buy a tractor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Rukhsana's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana started an embroidery business to fulfill the needs of her family after the death of her husband. She worked very hard and gained a lot of skills with the passage of time. Now her business is well established and she receives regular orders every month.  She is the mother of 2 sons and a daughter. Her youngest son is studying, while others are working to contribute financially to the family. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for the further expansion of her decorative embroidery business. With the loan, she will purchase embroidery material in bulk quantity that will allow her to prepare beautiful-looking embroidered clothes according to her customer's demands.  It should increase her profits.  She is very confident about her business and very sure that an investment will bring good changes to her business.  She will be able to save extra money in order to buy a dowry for her daughter’s marriage. 
Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rukhsana”.

loans.use: To buy embroidery material for decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Aizat's Group

texts.en:
Aizat is the treasurer of this group. She is 26 and married to a driver, whose monthly salary is 13,000 soms. Together with her husband, she brings up two children, both of whom are preschool age (under seven).  At the moment, Aizat has saved 55,000 soms.  She is applying for the loan because she needs some additional funds to purchase hosiery to start a trade in the local market. In the future with the profits gained from the trade she plans to purchase a container (shipping container converted to a home or market stall).

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase hosiery to sell

loans.name: Gantumur

texts.en:
Gantumur is 41 years old and lives with her sons and husband in a house in Ulaanbaatar city of Mongolia.  One son is a college student and the other son is a high school student. Her husband used to sell plastic bags at the local market. But now he is running a cellphone repair service and spare parts shop. Gantumur has two professions, tailoring and nursing. She used to work as a nurse from 1990 to 1994. From 2000, she started to run a tailoring business. Now she has many regular clients and has expanded her business successfully. Her turnover capital is 1,000,000 MNT. Her daily sales are 30,000 MNT. She keeps good control of her cash flow and expenses. When her income exceeds over 30,000 MNT, she saves the extra income in her savings account. Her sons take care of their family matters so that she and her husband can pay more attention to their businesses. She is a hardworking and diligent woman who says "When I and my husband come home after long work hours, my sons already cook the dinner and clean the home. I feel good about this. 

This year, we are not able to pay the full tuition fee of my son. If I could pay that fee, I would have nothing to worry about." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to pay for her son's tuition fee and increase the turnover capital of her husband's
business.

loans.use: To pay for her son's tuition fees

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en: Ganchimeg is 37 years old and lives with her five children and husband in a ger, Mongolian yurt, in Tosontsengel province of Mongolia. Her eldest daughter is a college student and another three are high school students. She started her business in 2001 by making and selling Mongolian traditional shoes at her home. She has already gained recognition from her clients and customers. She is planning to expand her business in the future. She is a hardworking and diligent woman who says "Our family has a college student. I want to pay the tuition fee to the university. Also I have a plan to expand my business and open a factory." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to buy materials to make shoes.

loans.use: To buy materials to make shoes

loans.name: Nyamsuren

texts.en: Nyamsuren is 49 years old and lives with his wife and children in a house in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar City, Mongolia. His two daughters are college students and his other two children are high school students. He started his business in 1995 by driving a taxi in his local town. His business is doing well and his daily income is between 20,000 MNT to 30,000 MNT. He is a diligent and hardworking man who says, "I want to give a very good education to my children and let them study at the university. This is my main goal in life." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to pay the tuition fees for his daughters.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees for his daughters.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is 38 years old.  She is married and has three children attending school. Marivic's spouse works as a local farmer. To increase the family's income, Marivic buys and sells plastics and used bottles to the people in the village where they live. She usually earns a daily profit of P200.  That is used for daily meals and the needs of her children.

She is now asking for a loan of P4,000 to have additional capital to buy more used bottles, magazines, plastics and cans and sell them to the junk shop. 
In the future, Marivic would like to earn consistent profits for the college education of her children.

loans.use: to buy more used bottles, magazines, plastics and cans to sell to the junk shop.

loans.name: Zinakan's Group

texts.en:
Zinakan is the leader of this group. She is 54 and married to a farmer. In order to earn money for their livelihood, Zinakan provides sewing services. She started this activity thirteen years ago with an initial investment of 2000 soms. With that money, she purchased a multi-functional sewing machine. At the moment her business runs well, she has a lot of orders, and she earns about 9300 soms per month. With money received from the loan Zinakan wants to purchase fabrics and materials which are needed for sewing.  In the future, with the profits gained from the business, she wishes to build a new house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Jainakul's Group

texts.en:
Jainakul is the treasurer of this group. She is 54 and married to a construction worker. Together with her husband, she brings up a daughter and a son. The daughter studies at school and the son works in construction. In order to earn additional money for their livelihood, Jainakul started to provide sewing services with an initial investment of 3000 soms ten years ago. She sews Kyrgyz national pillows and blankets. In this way, she earns about 10,000 soms per month. With the profits gained from the business, Jainakul purchased livestock for breeding.  With money received from the loan, she plans to purchase fabrics and materials which are needed for sewing. In the future Jainakul wants to see her children get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Ayesha's Group

texts.en:
Ayesha is married and has two children. Both of them are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. She supports her family by sewing clothes for neighboring clients. She is known among her clients for her good skills and receives regular orders every month. 

She has applied for a loan from a Kiva partner, Asasah, for the further expansion of her sewing business. She is confident that, by purchasing a new sewing machine, she will be able to complete her orders on time and increase her profits. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Ayesha.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her sewing business

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
Bushra is a working lady who sews clothes for her neighboring clients. She is very skillful in her work and receives a good number of orders every month. Her skills enable her to earn a reasonable amount of income. Her husband is a scrap dealer. He supplies scrap to different factories and to other scrap dealers. Bushra has given birth to eight children. Her eldest daughter left her education after matriculation and started an embroidery business. Four of her children are enrolled in a school and getting their education.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s scrap business. With the loan, he will  buy scrap like used papers, plastic bottles, and iron in bulk to be able to increase his sales and profits. Bushra hopes that through the loan investment her husband's business will be improved further. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Bushra.

loans.use: To buy scrap

loans.name: Kalemkash's Group

texts.en:
Kalemkash is the treasurer of this group. She is 45 years old. With her husband, she is raising two sons and a daughter. The sons study at university and the daughter is in school. Kalemkash works as a loan officer in the Financial Group “Kompanion.” She also breeds cattle. At the moment she keeps a cow, a bull, and three calves. Her husband helps her in running the business. Kalemkash applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase feed for the cattle. In the future she wishes to build a house for her sons.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase feed for cattle

loans.name: Jailobai

texts.ru: Жайлобаю 63 года, женат и имеет 2 детей. Начиная с 1991 года, Жайлобай со своей семьей занимается животноводством и полеводством.  Начав со стартовой суммы в 20,000 сом (KGS), Жайлобай  развил свое хозяйство с бычками, коровами и баранами.  В целях дополнительного источника дохода, по сезону Жайлобай предоставляет услуги комбайнера жителям близлежащих сел. Для дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Жайлобай	 обратился в компанию «Бай – Тушу м и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS)на покупку скота. Доходы от кредита он планирует вложить в увеличение поголовья, чтобы в будущем иметь возможность купить новый комбайн.
texts.en: Jailobai is 63 years old, he is married and has two children. Beginning in 1991 Jailobai and his family started a business in animal husbandry and agriculture. With a starting capital of 20,000 soms (KGS) Jailobai developed his business with calves, cows and lamb. With a goal to have an additional source of income Jailobai provides a season service of combine-harvester driver to the residents of the nearby villages. To further develop his business Jailobai has come to Bai-Tushum and Partners for a loan in the amount of 50,000 KGS to buy cattle. He plans to invest the profit from the loan to increase the headcount of cattle so that he may be able to buy a new combine in the future.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a 30-year-old married woman with three children, two of whom are in school. She has a charcoal sales business in Dar es Salam Branch in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years. Betty requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan to be able to order more charcoal to sell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Kanyshai's Group

texts.en:
Kanyshai is the leader of this group. She is 53 and, unfortunately, a widow. She has raised two sons and two daughters. The daughters are married and live separately with their families. The older son works in Russia, and the second son works as a security guard. Kanyshai works at school; she also breeds livestock. She keeps a cow and six goats. She resells livestock after fattening, which earns her an additional 2,000 KGS per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase five goats to increase the number of livestock she keeps. In the future Kanyshai wants to see her sons get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase goats

loans.name: Bunjojo Farmers Association Group

texts.en:
Dizzy is a hardworking married man with four children.  They live in a permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to educate his children up to university. He has been farming and selling agricultural products for the last 20 years and his desire is to farm on at least 100 acres of land despite the challenge of price fluctuation.

Dizzy needs the loan to plough land for farming.  Out of eighteen group members, only eleven took the loan and as a group policy each member guarantees for the others in accessing credit.

loans.use: To plough land for farming

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola is 21 years old.  She is a married woman with one child who is not yet in school.  She has a business selling clothes in Dar es Salaam in Yei, South Sudan.  She has been in this business for five years.

Viola requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase more clothes to sell.  She says that she will use the profits from this loan to build a shop to expand her business.

loans.use: buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Anweri

texts.en:
Anweri has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s corner juice business. He has a shop located in the market through which he sells different fruit juices. His juices are very popular among his customers and he makes good profits every month. 

Anweri is a housewife and performs her household duties by staying at home. She has given birth to 5 children. Her 2 elder sons work with their father, while the others are getting their education.  

With this loan, Anweri's husband will buy more juicer machines and also fresh fruits to serve many more customers without waiting.  He is very experienced in his business and has been operating it for the past 10 years. 

Anweri hopes that this investment will help her husband make more profits and her family will be able to live a better life as a result.  Anweri is a regular loan user of Asasah's and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: buy juicer machines & fruits

loans.name: Aiden

texts.en:
This is Aiden.  She is 38 years old and is a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. Her husband is Benjamin, a security guard.  Aiden is a mother of three children, two are studying in elementary school while one is still staying at home. She, together with her children, manages their own household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Aiden operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and  people in the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 350 in sales every day.  Aside from this, Aiden also sews rugs for added income. 

To help continue the operations of her business, Aiden is requesting a loan of Php 10,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Aiden hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy grocery items

loans.name: Sanyu

texts.en:
Sanyu is a 22-year-old married woman with two children, one of whom is in school.  She has a business selling clothes in Dar es Salaam in Yei, South Sudan.  She has been in this business for five years.

Sanyu requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business.

loans.use: buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella used the previous loan to educate her children but needs another loan to expand her business. She currently runs a retail shop that she started five years ago with a limited capital of only 2,000,000 shillings.  She faces a challenge in the high cost of rent and her dream is to own a wholesale shop.  Stella needs another loan to buy sugar, soap and rice to sell.

loans.use: buy sugar, soap and rice

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is a 34-year-old hardworking business woman.   She is married and is blessed with two children. For the past year, she has been selling coffins to earn a living. She also practices poultry farming. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Emily has been able to save her money and access business loans.  In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business. She is requesting for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more coffins to resell.

loans.use: buy coffins to resell

loans.name: Myra

texts.en:
This is Myra.  She is 38 years old and is a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Samuel, a mechanic, and is a mother of two children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Myra operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from the round palm-sized ones, to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, as well as other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, they are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Myra's regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 250 in sales every day.

To help continue the operations of her business, Myra is requesting a PHP 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing this loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Myra dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy materials to make rugs

loans.name: Aidha

texts.en:
Aidha is a 26-year-old woman, married to a businessman. They have two children, neither of whom are in school. She has a business selling clothes in the town of Dar es Salam, Yei county in South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years.
Aidha requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase more clothes for sale with the hopes of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to improve his shop and produce some digital ads.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is 31 years old and married with two children between the ages of three and five. For the last three years, he has been managing a retail shop to earn a living. He also practices poultry and livestock farming to supplement his income. He hopes to expand his business into wholesale in the future. With the 20,000 Kenya shillings loan, he wants to buy sugar and rice for resale.

loans.use: To buy sugar and rice for resale

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
This is Nida, 33, resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Jorge, an electrician, and the father of her two children. She, together with her husband, manages the household while operating their business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income to cover their daily expenses.

Nida operates an appliance repair shop. They have one full-time head technician and other on-call workers when needed. She handles finances, accounts, inventories, and promotion of their business. They offer repair and check-up of all types of appliances like TVs, washing machines, air conditioners, and others. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in service fees every day. 

To help her continue business operations, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will utilize the loan to buy appliance spare parts. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Nida hopes to open another shop in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy appliance spare parts needed in her business

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed is married and her husband has a business selling bed sheets. He puts the bed sheets on his bicycle and visits different places & markets. He is very experienced in his work and has been operating his business for many years. 
Khursheed is a housewife and also helps her husband in arranging the bed sheets on his bicycle. 
She has given birth to 6 children. Her eldest son also has a business selling bed sheets while the youngest one is studying. Her remaining children stay at home and do not work. 
Khursheed has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy bed sheets in larger quantities for sale. 
Khursheed hopes that an investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s business and will help her family to live better financially.

loans.use: To buy bed sheets for sale

loans.name: Hoda

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 35 years old, a widow and a mother to her two children.

Hoda has been a tailor since 2000. She makes, repairs, or alters clothing professionally, items such as suits, coats and trousers for women and kids. She has good experience in this field, a deep understanding of local customers, and knows about their needs. She has a good reputation and she is well known in the surrounding areas.

She is requesting $2100 to purchase two industrial sewing machines, a generator and to add more materials such as buttons, zippers, and thread. She is aiming to gain more profits to offer her the opportunity to provide a better life for her family as a whole.

loans.use: To purchase two industrial sewing machines, a generator and to add more materials such as buttons, zippers, and thread.

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en:
Cicilia is 45 years old and divorced with five children, one of whom is in school. She has a business selling charcoal in Dar es Salam branch in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years.

Cicilia requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase or order more charcoal to sell. She says that the profits from this loan will help her to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mai

texts.en: Mai was born in 1971. She is married with two children. Her family lives in Ngoc Loi village. She is a carpenter. She has a workshop at home. She has been working at this business for three years with her husband’s help. They produce wood furniture. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2006. This is the sixth time she borrowed a loan from SEDA. In the last cycle, she borrowed 7,194,000 VND to expand her workshop and she repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy wood to produce furniture.

loans.use: to buy wood to produce furniture.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en: Benson is married and blessed with two children who go to school. For the past seven years, he has been supplying building materials such as sand and ballast to earn a living. He has grown the business through the financial support of Faulu Kenya.  He also works as a taxi driver to get more income. In the next five years, he wants to expand his business. With the loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings, he wants to buy sand.

loans.use: To buy sand

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Benson

texts.en: Benson is a businessman, aged 36. He is married and blessed with three children. For the last nine years, he has been managing a grocery store to make a living.  Additionally, he is employed in a hardware shop hence he has employed one person to run his business in his absence. In the next 5 years, he wants to own a retail shop. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy onions and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy onions and vegetables

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 29-year-old married woman but she has no child. She has a business selling bread in the Dar es Salaam branch, Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Betty requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business. She will use the extra income from this loan for building a concrete house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more bread for sale.

loans.name: Haydar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq.  He is 32 years old, married and the father of six children.

Haydar has been the owner of a workshop that repairs and fixes generators since 2006.  He has more than eight years of experience in this field and a good reputation.  He is well known in the surrounding areas.

He is requesting a $3,000 loan to build a sliding door, shelves and to purchase a repair kit and parts.  He aims to make more profits and improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: fix his shop and buy car parts.

loans.name: Jassem

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 46 years old, married and a father of one child who works with him.

Jassem has owned an herbal shop since 2009 where he sells bulk herbs, spices, medicinal herbs, aromatherapy, therapeutic essential oils, botanicals and essential oils for restaurants, health food stores, herbalists, bakers, family farms, soap makers and perfumes. He has sufficient experience in herbs and how to prepare them. He has a good reputation and he is well-known in the surrounding area.

He is requesting an $1800 loan in order to buy a three-wheel truck and generator. He is aiming to gain more profit to improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a three-wheel truck and generator.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is 51 years old, married, and a father of three children ages 25, 21,and 19. He runs a butcher shop and has been in this business for 23 years with a monthly income of KES. 20,000.

He has applied for a loan of KES. 60,000 to purchase goats and sheep for slaughter. He plans to use the anticipated profit from the business to buy more stock.

This is his third loan after successfully paying back his previous loans. His dreams and hopes are to continue with his business and to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy goats and sheep for slaughter

loans.name: Nisrine

texts.en:
Nisrine is a 28-year-old single lady from Lebanon. She started a women's beauty business eight years ago. Nisrine is a hard worker. She is loved by most of her customers who are mainly her relatives, friends and neighbors. 

Nisrine works hard to improve her business. She previously requested a loan form Al Majmoua, Kiva's partner, in order to buy new machines, tools and products for her business. This is Nisrine's third cycle as a Al Majmoua borrower. Her previous loans were a perfect investment. This time the loan is to be used for her wedding needs and preparations and to pay for her wedding organizer. She hopes to expand her beauty salon more and more in the future, by opening a special treatment sector dealing with all facial and special skin medications.

loans.use: to pay for her wedding organizer

loans.name: Nenesa

texts.en:
Nenesa is a 40-year-old married woman with five children, three of whom are in school. She has a business seling fish in the town of Dar es Salam, Yei county in South Sudan. She has been in this business for six years.
Nenesa requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to enable her to purchase more fish for sale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for sale

loans.name: Alias

texts.en:
Alias is a 32-year-old a married woman with four children, two of whom are in the school.  She has a business selling beans, flour, onions, etc. in Dar es Salaam in Yei, South Sudan.  She has been in this business for five years.

Alias requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business.  She will use the extra income to build a house in the future.

loans.use: buy beans, flour, onions

loans.name: Bahriddin

texts.ru: Бахриддин житель района Пяндж. Ему 27 лет. Он женат. У него 8 детей. Он более года предоставляет услугу, такси. Бахриддин развозит людей по району. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины. Он хочет обновить салон своего автомобиля.
texts.en: Bahriddin lives in the Pyandj district.  He is 27 years old, married and has 8 children.  He has been providing a taxi service for over one year.  Bahriddin transports people across the district.  He is requesting this loan to repair his car.  Bahriddin wants to update his car interior.

loans.use: to repair his car

loans.name: Jemimah

texts.en: Jemimah is a hardworking business lady.  She is 22 years old and is married. For the last three years, she has been selling clothes to earn a living. She has grown her business through Faulu Kenya and has managed to employ one person.  In the next 5 years, she wants to become successful in her business. She is requesting for a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy clothes.

loans.use: buy clothes

loans.name: Parisa

texts.en:
Parisa is a resident of Karajygach, a nice village in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 44 years old and is unfortunately a widow.  She is bringing up three children: two sons and a daughter.  Her sons study at school while her daughter is still of pre-school age. 

Seven years ago, with an initial investment of 5000 soms, Parisa started to sell grocery goods. In this way, she earns 4500 soms to meet the family needs. With the profits gained from the trade, she was able to purchase a calf.  

Parisa has saved some money, but needs additional funds to purchase furniture for her home to improve the living conditions for her family.  For this purpose, she has applied for a loan. In the future, she wants to improve her business and provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchase home furniture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy banana seedlings

loans.name: Anmar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 24 years old, married and a father of one child.

Anmar has been an owner of a food market since 2009. He sells soft drinks, juices, cheese and dairy products. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs.  He has sufficient experience from his previous work with his father. His market is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by.

He decided to apply for a $1,500 loan in order to pay the annual rent and to add more foodstuffs to his shop. He is aiming to gain more profits to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: to pay the annual rent and to buiy more foodstuffs.

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
A caring lady, Rani manages her household chores by staying at home. She takes care of her family by cooking good food. Her husband gifted her a sewing machine, which she uses to sew clothes for her neighboring clients. She operates it when she gets free from her household work. She loves to do good for her family.   

Rani has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who has a furniture polisher business.  With the loan, he will buy polish and brushes to provide better quality services to his customers and increase his profits.  He is an experienced businessman and has been operating his business for many years. Rani is confident that an investment will take his business to a more profitable position. 

This is Rani's 2nd loan application to Asasah. In her previous loan year, she paid installments regularly without any problem. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rani.

loans.use: to buy polish and brushes

loans.name: Su'ad

texts.en:
Su'ad is a 35-year-old young woman.  She is married and has four sons and two daughters.  Her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a modest salary. Su'ad has her own project, which is selling vegetables, and she needs to purchase more vegetables to have a better collection to increase her sales and improve her income. 

Su'ad doesn't have enough money to buy more vegetables, so she needs to take a loan of $3,000 from FATEN.  When Su'ad gets the FATEN loan,  which is repaid on a monthly basis, she will be able to purchase more vegetables and have a  better collection for sale.  In this way, she will increase her income and enable her family to live in better life conditions. 

Su'ad is a conservative woman, so her son Mohammad who is 18 years old is photographed in the place she sells her vegetables.

loans.use: buy vegetables

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 21 years old.  She is a single woman with no children.  She has a business selling breads in Dar es Salaam in Yei, South Sudan.  She has been in this business for five years. She also earns some income from selling vegetables.

Mary requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business.  She will use the profit to build a house in the future.

loans.use: buy breads to sell

loans.name: Ghazwan

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq.  He is 22 years old, single and lives with two family members.

Ghazwan has been the owner of a bakery since 2007.  He produces and sells flour-based food baked in an oven, such as bread, cakes, pastries and pies. He has four years of experience in this field and a good reputation.  His bakery is situated in a crowded area where there are a good number of customers passing by.

He is requesting a $3,000 loan to purchase a large electric dough machine.  He aims to increase profits and provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: purchase a large electric dough machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a second-hand motorbike

loans.name: Ma'rifat

texts.ru: Маърифат проживает в районе Пяндж. Она замужем. Ей 43 года. Она имеет шестерых детей. Ее муж находится в России. Сама она имеет среднее образование. Более 20 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном продает овощи и еще она занимается нарезкой и торговлей моркови для приготовления плова. Она берет кредит для покупки овощей и фруктов.
texts.en: Ma'rifat lives in the Pyandj district.  She is 43 years old, married and has six children.  Her husband is in Russia.  She has a secondary education.  Ma'rifat has been involved in sales at a market for over 20 years.  She primarily sells vegetables and is also involved in cutting and selling carrots for preparing pilaf.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of vegetables and fruits.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Ikram

texts.en:
Ikram is a 41-year-old married woman and mother to two beautiful children. To help her husband with their family's income, Ikram started a small business three years ago.  She works as a tailor making curtains and living room shields.  She also fixes dresses and makes beautiful new ones.  Ikram also sells underwear, in addition to towels and winter blankets. She is a multi-business woman who works hard to keep her business running and improving.

Ikram is experiencing an Al Majmoua loan for the first time.  She knew about it from her neighbor, who gave her a very positive and impressive feedback about his loan through Al Majmoua-KIVA and his business progress, and now she's very excited to share her experience with them.

Her requested loan will be used to buy a new sewing machine and its tools.  This machine will help in doing extra jobs in less time and with perfect quality.  Ikram hopes to open a big tailoring factory in the future to expand her business as much as she can, and to make sure her family's future is secured.

loans.use: buy a sewing machine and its tools

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity is a 57-year-old business woman.  She is married and is blessed with five children. For the last 30 years, she has been rearing dairy goats and growing vegetables.  In addition, she also runs a green grocery for extra income.  In the next 5 years, she wants to become the major supplier of milk in her region.  Charity is requesting a loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings to buy fertilizer for her farm.

loans.use: buy fertilizer

loans.name: Adel

texts.en: Adel is a 30-year-old single man from Lebanon living with his parents. He has been working at the Internal Security Forces since 2004. In parallel, since 2005, he has been working in computer repair in order to get a higher income and better support his family. With the requested loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l, he will be able to purchase a car which will help him with transportation to facilitate his work especially since he serves customers located in different places and areas. In the future, Adel hopes to open his own computer shop.

loans.use: to purchase a car which will help him with transportation to customers

loans.name: Chuluuntogtokh

texts.en:
Mr.Chuluuntogtokh always worries about his family's house which is in bad condition currently. He says the roof is so bad that rain water leaks through. He is a 24-year-old taxi driver. He lives with his wife, 3-year-old son, mother and two brothers. He has been running his taxi business for three years and has a number of loyal customers. He is a self-motivated and hardworking young man. 

Mr.Chuluuntogtokh requested a loan to purchase building materials for making repairs to his house to improve conditions for his family.

loans.use: to purchase building materials for repairing his house.

loans.name: Chuma Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from members of Chuma SHG group in Western Kenya! Samwel is the facilitator of the Chuma SHG group. These farmers reside in the Chwele district. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Samwel and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

Samwel takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds to ensure food security for his family and educate his children. In the recent 2011 season, Samwel improved upon past harvests with a maize yield of seven bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Samwel was only able to harvest five bags of maize on that land. 

With income from maize sales, Samwel will invest in building a house, and in livestock. 

In 2012, the members of Chuma SHG group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

In the photograph above, Samwel is pictured with his group members with the Field Officer (Bonface) at the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Sergelen

texts.en: Mr.Sergelen is a 45-year-old father of three children. He lives in a Mongolian ger (a nomadic tent) which is cold during the winter. He has been driving a company car for six years and is one of the best drivers at the company. His wife works at home as a tailor taking orders from customers. She has been doing this business for many years. This is Mr. Sergelen's third loan request and he has repaid all previous loans successfully. As he said the Mongolian ger is very cold during the winter and he is worried about his family's health and comfort. The loan he requested will be used to buy a warm roof for the ger and repair his vehicle for better service.

loans.use: To buy a warm roof for the ger and repair his vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard is a hardworking businessman, aged 35. He is married and blessed with three children who are still in school. For the last three years, he has been selling cooking pans and baskets to earn a living. He also practices livestock farming to supplement his income. He works hard in his business so as to provide for his family.  In the next 5 years, he wants to manage a wholesale business.  He is requesting a loan of 45,000 Kenya shillings to buy baskets and cooking pans.

loans.use: To buy cooking pans and baskets.

loans.name: Anis

texts.en: Anis is a 62-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and only child. He is the main income provider for his family. He has been working as a vegetable trader for the past 40 years. He works on a freelance basis, distributing goods using his van. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase more vegetables. He plans to expand his business by increasing his sales and, therefore, his profits. In the future, he intends to hire a part-time employee to help him with product distribution.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables

loans.name: 03.13.92 Vạn Hà Thiệu Hóa Group

texts.en:
Hương is 32 years old and is married with 2 children. Hương is the group leader of the 03.13.92 Vạn Hà solidarity group, which consists of 4 members. She lives and works in the Thiệu Hóa district, a rural area in the Thanh Hoa province, with 2 dependents.

Mrs Hương works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. The main hardship that Hương faces in her business is the lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell in the future. 

This is Hương's first loan with the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. With her business profit, Hương hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, for her business to do well, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Gansukh

texts.en: Gansukh is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children. Two of his children attend secondary school and the youngest is only two years old. Gansukh delivers construction materials with his truck. Unfortunately, his business is highly seasonal. During the winter, he sells coal and wood to earn more income. With his hard work, their living conditions have improved steadily. His wife used to work as a salesperson for her brother’s clothing stall, but now she wants to sell clothes on her own. She believes that it will help increase her family's earnings. Gansukh is requesting a loan for his wife to purchase clothing products from wholesalers to start her sales business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing products from wholesalers to start his wife's sales business.

loans.name: 03.03.93 Thiệu Trung Thiệu Hóa Group

texts.en:
Mai is 45 years old and is married with 3 children. Mai is the group leader of the 03.03.93 Thiệu Trung solidarity group, which consists of 3 members. She lives and works in the Thiệu Hóa district, a rural area in the Thanh Hoa province, with 1 dependent.

Mrs Mai works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle. She has been involved in this business for 8 years. The main hardship that Mai faces in her business is the lack of skills. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell in the future. 

This is Mai's first loan with the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. With her business profit, Mai hopes to buy land of her own, for her business to do well, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married and blessed with three children. For the past two years, she has been selling cereals to make a living. She is a determined to make her business successful. In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business into wholesale. With the loan of 80,000 Kenya shillings, she wants to buy beans and a weighing machine.

loans.use: To buy beans and a weighing machine

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 56-year-old married man who has two children for whom he works hard to improve and secure their living conditions. Ali sells fruit and vegetables. His trade is going fine but such a business needs daily care to ensure his products are healthy and fresh.
Good quality products are what differentiates him from others.
Most of his customers are from his village and a good number of foreigners stop at his shop because of its good location on Ain's main road.
Ali is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to increase his stock with special seasonal fruit and vegetables at good prices and with special offers.
He plans to start wholesale trade but he needs more capital to take this step.

loans.use: To increase his stock with new season fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en: Douglas is a hardworking business man aged 44. He is married and blessed with four children. For the past six years, he has been practicing dairy farming to earn a living. He also does horticultural farming. In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business. He is requesting a loan of 100,000 Kenya shillings to buy two dairy cows.

loans.use: To buy two dairy cows

loans.name: Wesakulila Group

texts.en:
Jane is the facilitator of the Wesakulila group. Jane and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jane and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

Jane takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to ensure food security for her family and to have enough money to educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Jane had an excellent maize yield harvesting 13 bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jane was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With income from maize sales, Jane will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Wesakulila group will each plant between ½ and one acre of land. 

In the photograph above, Jane is pictured with her group members, with her field officer on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her family business of selling animals (goats).  
She is a multi-business owner. She also sews clothes for her neighbors. With the loan, she will buy animals like goats to sell to butchers after raising them. 
Her husband also has an animal sales business. Both Khursheed and her husband started this business 15 years ago and now have a vast knowledge in their field of work. 
She has given birth to 3 daughters and a son. Due to financial constraints, she couldn’t provide an education for their children. All of them stay at home and provide support to their parents in their businesses. 
Khursheed is very confident that, after the loan investment, she will be able to increase her profits and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: To buy animals (goats) for her animal sales business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a 39-year-old married woman with three children, two of whom are in the school. She is married to a construction worker. She sells fish in Dar es Salam branch in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years. She also earns some income from selling beans and onions.
Agnes requested this loan through BRAC, South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business. The extra income will be used to build a house for her children in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for sale.

loans.name: Hosbayar

texts.en: Hosbayar is 35 years old and lives with his children and wife in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in the Tosontsengel province of Mongolia. His children are high school students. His wife makes Mongolian traditional shoes and also supports the family business. He started his carpentry business nine years ago and is now operating at his local hometown. In the future, he plans to expand his business. He is a diligent and hardworking man who says, "My wife used to make Mongolian traditional shoes and then she quit. Now she is making them again. This really helps our family. While [our] children are young, we want to make the family business expanded and grown. I want to improve my life and expand my business so much." He is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) loan to purchase sewing materials for shoes and more wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase sewing materials for making shoes and more wood for his business.

loans.name: Kisiwa Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kisiwa SHG in Western Kenya! Irine is the facilitator of the Kisiwa SHG group. Irine and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Irine takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Irine had an very good maize yield harvesting eight bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Irine was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Irine and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Irine will pay school fees for her kids, and possibly buy livestock. 

In 2012, the members of Kisiwa SHG group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

In the photograph above, Irine is pictured with her group members. Note that of the five women in this group, four are present, as one (Jackline) was being represented by her husband (far right) at the meeting during which this photograph was taken. On the far left is Irine's field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jypara

texts.en: Jypara is a resident of Karajygach, a nice village in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 27 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she brings up a son and two daughters. The older daughter studies at school and the other children are preschool age. Three years ago, with an initial investment 5,000 soms, the family started to breed livestock. At the moment they keep four goats, and their monthly profit from reselling livestock is about 4,500 soms. Jypara applies for the loan because she needs additional financial funds to purchase a calf for breeding. In the future, she wants to provide her children with a good education. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a hardworking businessman aged 58. He is married and blessed with four children. For the last 11 years, he has been managing a retail shop to make a living. He works hard in his business so as to provide for his family, including educating his children.  

In the next five years, he wants to manage a wholesale business. With the loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings, he wants to buy soda, maize flour, soap and cooking fat.

loans.use: To buy soda, maize flour, soap and cooking fat.

loans.name: Vera

texts.ru:
Вера замужем, у нее есть взрослая замужняя дочь. Она - рыночный предприниматель из Белой Церкви. Вера работает на местном Центральном рынке, продавая трусы, носки, майки и т.д. Этим бизнесом Вера решила заняться еще 15 лет назад и с тех пор каждый день она торгует данным видом товара на рынке. Благодаря своему бизнесу Вера смогла помочь своей дочери тоже начать собственный бизнес и она тоже теперь торгует на местном базаре. 

Кредит в 7 000 гривен Вера планирует использовать для того, чтобы увеличить ассортимент нижнего белья на продажу. На данный момент чистая прибыль Веры составляет около 3 000 гривен, но Вера не хотела бы останавливаться на достигнутом и планирует в будущем еще открыть киоск в собственном дворе, где она смогла бы продавать продукты питания.

Пометка: история на РУССКОМ языке
texts.en: Vera is married and has a grown daughter.  She is a market entrepreneur from Belaya Tserkov.  Vera works at the local Central market, selling underpants, socks, tank tops and etc.  Vera decided to start this business 15 years ago and, since then, has been selling this merchandise every day at the market.  Thanks to her business, Vera was able to help her daughter to start her own business too, and she now sells at the local market.  Vera plans to use the 7,000 hryvnia loan to expand the assortment of undergarments for sale.  Her current net profit is about 3,000 hryvnia, but Vera does not want to stop with what she has achieved and in the future plans to open another kiosk in her own yard, where she could sell food products.

loans.use: to expand assortment of undergarments for sale

loans.name: Khosiyat

texts.ru: Хосият проживает в районе Пяндж. Возраст, 40 лет. Она разведена. Она уже четыре года занимается торговлей. Хосият занимается торговлей нижнего белья, пастельного белья и мужских брюк. Она берет кредит для приобретения теплых свитеров, женского и мужского нижнего белья, футболок и шапок.
texts.en: Khosiyat lives in the Pyandj district.  She is 40 years old and divorced.  She has been involved in retail sales for four years.  Khosiyat sells undergarments, bedding and men's trousers.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of new warm sweaters, women's and men's undergarments, tee-shirts and hats.

loans.use: to buy new warm sweaters, women's and men's undergarments, tee-shirts and hats

loans.name: Bashiraan's Group

texts.en:
Bashiraan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s fruit and vegetable shop. He has been operating his shop for the past four years and provides fresh, quality products to his clients at reasonable rates. 

With the loan, he will buy fresh, seasonal fruits and vegetables in bulk to put in his shop for selling. 

Bashiraan herself is a housewife and does her household responsibilities. She also supports her husband by cleaning the fruits and vegetables with water every day before her husband takes them to his shop for selling. 

She also knows the art of sewing and works as a seamstress on a part-time basis. She is the mother of three children; all of them are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education.
 
She is very hopeful that after the loan investment, her husband will be able to expand his business and earn better profits that will help her children continue their education and also enhance the living standards of her family. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and has never missed any meetings.
 
Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called the Asasah Passbook) is Bashiraan.

loans.use: To buy fresh, seasonal fruits and vegetables for selling.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 38 years old. She is a married woman with seven children, four of whom are in school. She has a business of selling chicken in Dar es Salam in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for six years.

Alice requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business to purchase more chickens for sale. The extra income will be used for paying the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for sale.

loans.name: Gereltuya

texts.en:
Gereltuya is 44 years old and lives with her children and husband in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in the Sansar district of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her daughter is a college graduate but currently helps her family's business. Her son is a high school student. Her husband used to work in the military but retired early. Now he stays at home. 

Gereltuya earned her certificate in tailoring and fashion design from the Russian training center. She started her business in 2003 by selling clothes with the bank loan of 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). In 2009, she got sick and went to China for medical care. Now she is recovered. Although her business was forgotten for two years, she continued her business successfully by opening two trading places at the local market and another one in Darhan city. 

In the future, she plans to expand her business, buy a car and build a house. She is a hardworking and diligent woman who says, "I used to take loans from other places at higher interest rates. Now I can see that XacBank offers me loans with reasonable interest rates and other conditions." 

She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy clothes from China and diversify the products for her business. She also mentions that the winter season is coming and people will buy more clothes.

loans.use: To buy clothes from China.

loans.name: Neema C Group

texts.en:
Eunice is the facilitator of the Neema C group, in the Chwele district of Western Kenya. Eunice and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Eunice and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

Eunice takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to ensure food security for her family and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the 2011 season, Eunice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, she was only able to harvest five bags of maize on that land. 

With income from maize sales, Eunice will educate her children and pay back her loan. 

In 2012, the members of Neema C group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land. 

In the photograph above, Eunice is pictured with her group members, plus a child of one of the group members.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan is a 44-year-old married woman and mother of five children. Hanan is a hard working woman, she started her own business in 2009 when she opened a household appliances retail shop. 

Hanan lives in a Palestinian camp, and she works hard to improve her family's living through improving her business and income. To do so, Hanan applied for a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy new collections and designs attractive to new customers. Hanan loves her business a lot, and she works hard on improving it from time to time. She plans to expand it in the future through adding a new plastics department. 

Hanan is a woman with a very good reputation, she is active and loved by most of her customers. Hanan is experiencing Al Majmoua loans for the first time, and she hopes this experience will sprout impressive results.

loans.use: To increase her merchandise with new household items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To acquire more temporary housing to rent out

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 28 years old and a married woman with three children, one of whom is in school. She is married to a man who is a teacher. She has a business selling breads in Dar es Salam branch in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years. 

Rose requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase more bread to sell

loans.name: Mehrob

texts.ru: Мехроб занимается купля продажей продукты питания. Он имеет магазин, в котором продает широкий ассортимент продукты питания. Он начинал данный бизнес с 5000 Сомони а постепенно увеличивал свой оборотный капитал. Его торговая точка находится в жилом районе города и вблизи от его магазина находиться профилакторий, что благоприятно влияет на его торговлю. От данного бизнеса он получает стабильный доход, и он очень хочет расширить свой бизнес и увеличить ассортимента продукта. С этой целью Мехроб запрашивает займ в размере 12000 Сомони.
texts.en: Mehrob is involved in buying and selling food products.  He has a store, where he sells a wide assortment of food products.  He started his business with 5000 Somoni and gradually increased his revolving capital.  Mehrob's store is located in a residential neighborhood of the town, and there is a treatment facility near his store, which positively affects his sales.  He earns a stable income from this business, wants to expand his business and expand an assortment of products.  This is why Mehrob is requesting a loan in the sum of 12000 Somoni.

loans.use: to buy a new assortment of food products

loans.name: Kulmira's Group

texts.en:
Kulmira is the leader of this group. She is 52 and unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised two children; both of them are married and live independently from their mom. 

Kulmira works in the Center of Children and Youth Tourism and she is also engaged in livestock breeding. She has big experience in this sphere; she has been running her livestock breeding business for 29 years. With the profits gained from this business she was able to purchase a piece of land in Bishkek and a vehicle for her son. With money received from the loan Kulmira wants to purchase sheep for breeding, fattening and further reselling. In the future she plans to start building a house.



--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a hardworking business man aged 47. He is married and blessed with three children. 

For the last 16 years he has been selling clothes to make a living. He also practices poultry farming to supplement his income. In the next 5 years he wants to expand his business. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy shirts and blouses for resale.

loans.use: To buy shirts and blouses to sell

loans.name: Subhon

texts.ru: Субхон житель района Истаравшан. Он женат. Ему 50 лет. У него двое детей. Его жена занимается бизнесом, она в основном продает орехи. А его дети учатся в средней школе. Сам Субхон занимается животноводством. Разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота и материальной помощи жене в ее бизнесе.
texts.en: Subhon lives in the Istaravshan district.  He is 50 years old, married and has two children.  His wife is involved in business; she primarily sells nuts.  And their children attend a secondary school.  Subhon is involved in animal husbandry.  He breeds livestock for subsequent sale.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle and provide financial help for his wife's business.

loans.use: to buy cattle and provide financial help for his wife's business

loans.name: Kizza

texts.en:
Kizza is 44 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, with four of them currently in school. For the past 9 years, Kiza has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand his business, Kizza has requested a loan of 2,200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential commodities like soap for resale, and it will help Kizza to generate greater profits and expand his business. Kizza hopes that in the future he will be able to open up a bakery business and supply the town with bread. 

Kizza is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Kizza who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more essential commodities like soap for resale.

loans.name: Shity

texts.en:
Shity is 34 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past six years, Shity has been working hard to manage her cosmetic shop, which sells body lotions. 

To help expand her business, Shity has requested a loan of 2,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more body lotions for resale, and it will help Shity to generate greater profits and increase her capital. In the future, Shity wants to own a beauty shop in town. 

Shity is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Shity who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more body lotions for resale.

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr:
Koffi est un homme de 22 ans, il est célibataire et n’a pas d’enfant.
Koffi  est un revendeur depuis 2010. Il achète et revend pour sa clientèle composée de toutes personnes des cartes de recharges. Il s’approvisionne auprès des sociétés de communication de Lomé. Koffi sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour l’achat de diverses cartes de recharges
texts.en:
Koffi is 22 years old, single and has no children. 

Koffi has been a small-scale retailer since 2010. He buys telephone recharge cards and retails them to his varied clientele. He buys from communications companies in Lomé. Koffi is asking WAGES for his first loan to buy various sorts of telephone cards.

loans.use: to buy telephone recharge cards.

loans.name: Pouaneoe

texts.fr:
Pouaneoe est une femme  âgé(e) de 34ans. Elle est mariée å un commerçant. Elle a 02 enfants en charge.
Pouaneoe travaille comme revendeuse de produits d’alimentation générale depuis 2005. Elle sert ses clients dans un quartier de la place après achat au Grand Marché de Lomé.
Pouaneoe a requis son premier cycle de prêt à WAGES afin d’acheter 05 bidons d’huile, 02 sacs de riz, 05 cartons de tomates, 03 cartons de lait et 03 sacs de sucre.
texts.en:
Pouaneoe is a woman of 34. She is married to a retailer and raising two children. 

Pouaneoe has been working selling foodstuffs since 2005. She serves customers in a local neighborhood after buying her supplies at the Grand Marché of  Lomé.

Pouaneoe requested her first loan from WAGES in order to buy five jerrycans of oil, two sacks of rice, five cartons of tomatoes, three cartons of milk, and three sacks of sugar.

loans.use: to buy grocery items (rice, sugar, tomatoes, milk) for resale.

loans.name: Montaser

texts.en:
